The disquiet had been replaced by a strange, quiet sense of purpose. He was a reader of signs, a translator of sorrow. He drove not to the precinct, but back to the waterfront, watching the tide begin its slow, inexorable journey up the beach. It would wash away the place where Maya Solis had made her last, beautiful, terrible piece of art, but it would not wash away the memory. The memory was his to carry now. His phone buzzed, a new call, a new case, a new story waiting to be read. He answered it, his voice calm and steady. "DCI Brent." The rain began to fall, not as a seep, but as a clean, simple patter on the windscreen, each droplet a tiny, clear lens reflecting the world back at him, complete in all its terrible, human, and haunted beauty.The voice on the other end of the line was young, sharp with a panicky adrenaline that cut through the calm patter of the rain. It was a patrol constable, fresh out of the academy by the sound of him, calling from a downtown condo tower that glittered with the cold, impersonal light of new money. It was a missing persons call, but the constable’s training had told him something was wrong enough to bypass the usual channels and route the call directly to the Major Crime Unit. Something about the scene felt off, a quiet wrongness he couldn’t articulate but that had raised the hairs on his neck. Brent listened, his gaze fixed on the water beading on his windscreen, and felt a familiar, quiet hum of anticipation. A new story was beginning.

He met Sharma in the lobby of the building, a sterile expanse of polished concrete and recessed lighting that smelled of cleaning fluid and ambition. The young constable, whose name was Miller, looked profoundly relieved to see them, as if he were handing over a volatile, ticking package. He led them up in a silent, high-speed elevator to the seventh floor. The apartment belonged to a man named Julian Finch, a digital cartographer for a local geo-tech firm. He hadn’t shown up for work in two days, and after he’d missed a daily check-in call with his sister, she had asked for a wellness check. The building manager had let Miller in. There was no sign of violence, no overt disturbance. Julian Finch was simply gone.

The apartment itself was a paradox. The layout was the generic, open-plan design of a thousand modern condos, but the space had been colonized by a sprawling, obsessive passion. On one wall, a bank of high-resolution monitors displayed shimmering, three-dimensional LIDAR scans of the city’s terrain, layers of data rendered in stark, ghostly colours. On the opposite wall, pinned with delicate archival tape, were fragile, sepia-toned sea charts from the nineteenth century. Books on urban planning, geology, and history were stacked in precarious towers on the floor. The entire apartment felt like a collision between two centuries, a workspace dedicated to stitching together the city’s past and its present. And in the very centre of the room, on a massive, antique drafting table, lay the heart of the mystery.

It was a vast, beautifully preserved 1890s map of Victoria and the surrounding peninsula. It was a work of art, its faded inks detailing a city that was a ghost of its modern self. But it had been altered. Someone, with an incredibly steady hand and a blade as sharp as a surgeon’s scalpel, had performed a careful, meticulous act of vandalism. They had not slashed or destroyed the map. They had edited it. With painstaking precision, they had cut away specific features. Not the roads, not the buildings, not the property lines, but the natural geography. The blue, spidery lines of every creek and stream that had long since been buried in culverts were gone, leaving behind empty, winding channels in the old paper. The faint green cross-hatching that marked swamps and marshlands had been surgically excised. The map had been blinded to its own aquatic past, its hidden veins and arteries severed, leaving it sterile and incomplete.

Sharma walked the perimeter of the room, her eyes sharp, logging the details for a report that would struggle to contain them. "No forced entry. Wallet and keys are on the kitchen counter. His car is in the underground parking. His work laptop is still here, powered on. No signs of a struggle. It’s a perfect vanishing act." She stopped beside the drafting table and looked down at the mutilated map, her expression a mixture of professional curiosity and a new, deeper understanding. "But he left a note. Or someone did." Brent, who had been crouched by the table, running a finger along the edge of one of the empty channels, looked up. "This isn't a note, Izzy," he said softly. "This is an erasure. A redaction. The killer, or the kidnapper, isn't telling us something. They're showing us what we are no longer allowed to see. They’re un-mapping the world."

The victim’s sister, a tense, articulate woman named Chloe, met them in the hushed lobby an hour later. Her face was pale with worry, her hands twisting the strap of her purse. "Julian wasn’t just a map-maker," she explained, her voice trembling slightly. "He was a historical detective. He called it ‘ghost geography.’ He was obsessed with the city that lies buried under the modern one. The streams, the shorelines, the old pathways. He believed that if you could map the forgotten landscape, you could understand the city’s real soul." Her eyes filled with tears. "He called me two nights ago. He was excited, more than I’ve heard him in years. He said he’d found one. A big one. A place that wasn’t on any of the modern maps, but that was clear as day on the old ones. A place that someone had gone to great lengths to make disappear, both physically and on paper."

Later, sitting in the quiet of their car as the evening deepened, the pieces began to coalesce into a familiar, unsettling shape. Brent had taken a photograph of the redacted map, and it was displayed on the car’s central screen, the empty riverbeds like pale scars on the old paper. "Chloe said Julian was working on a commission for a private client," Sharma said, scrolling through her notes on her phone. "A wealthy family, old name in the city. The Blackwoods. They wanted a comprehensive historical survey of their estate out in Metchosin. A massive tract of land that’s been in their family since the 1870s." She looked up from her phone and met Brent’s gaze. The unspoken connection hummed between them. The Collector case had been about land, too, about the foundational sins of the city's architects. This felt like a new verse of the same old, dark song.

"The Blackwoods," Brent murmured, his mind already sifting through the archives of his memory. "Reclusive. Intensely private. They’ve spent generations cultivating an aura of quiet, unassailable power. They don’t like people digging into their history." He looked at the glowing image of the map, then pointed to a large, surgically excised patch of green near the western edge of the peninsula, deep within the area that would have been the original Blackwood estate. "Julian wasn't just mapping lost streams. He was mapping lost secrets. He found something on the Blackwood property, something that wasn't supposed to exist anymore. And the kidnapper has responded in the same symbolic language. They haven’t just taken Julian Finch. They’ve taken the map out of his head. They’ve redacted the man who knew the way." The case was not a missing person. It was a carefully curated absence, a story told by what was no longer there, and they were the only two detectives in the city who knew how to read a void.The following morning, the city awoke to a crisp, sunlit clarity that felt like a lie. Brent and Sharma sat in the quiet of a waterfront café, the redacted map from Julian Finch’s apartment glowing on a tablet screen between them like a sacred, wounded text. The smell of salt and coffee filled the air, a familiar comfort that did little to soothe the unsettling nature of their new case. They were mapping a void, and the edges of that void led directly to the gates of the Blackwood estate.

“We can’t go in hard,” Sharma said, her voice a low murmur that wouldn't carry to the nearby tables. She traced the edge of an excised stream on the screen with her finger. “The Collector case taught us that much. The Blackwoods will have lawyers that can tie this department in knots for a decade. A search warrant based on a missing man and a cut-up map won’t even get past a duty judge.”

“You’re right,” Brent agreed. “This isn't a door we can kick down. We have to be invited in.” He looked out at the sunlight sparkling on the harbour, his mind formulating a strategy. “We approach them not as police investigating a crime, but as colleagues showing professional courtesy. We are here to inform them that Mr. Finch, the cartographer they commissioned, has gone missing. We’re concerned for his well-being, and since his last known project was for them, we feel they have a right to know. We are simply gathering information about his final days. It’s a polite inquiry, not an accusation.”

Sharma nodded, a slow, calculated motion. “A quiet conversation. We become a problem they feel they can manage, not a threat they need to destroy.” She picked up her coffee cup, her gaze intent. “And while you’re having a polite conversation, I’ll be taking inventory. Security cameras, staff, access roads, the layout of the grounds. We learn the terrain before we plan the invasion.” The language of warfare was a reflex for her, but Brent knew her meaning had shifted. The invasion wasn’t about tactical teams anymore; it was about the careful, deliberate insertion of the truth into a place that had been designed to repel it.

The drive out to Metchosin was a journey backwards in time. The neat, manicured suburbs of the city frayed at the edges, dissolving into winding country roads flanked by dense, shadowed forests of Douglas fir and arbutus. The air grew heavier, thick with the scent of damp earth and woodsmoke. This was old land, a part of the island that had stubbornly resisted the geometric overlay of modern development. They were entering a different kind of territory, one governed by older rules. The Blackwood estate was not announced by an ostentatious gate, but by a subtle, yet absolute, change in the landscape. The wild, untamed forest on one side of the road became, on the other, a manicured wilderness. The trees were the same, but they stood in a park-like order, the undergrowth cleared with meticulous care. It was nature, but nature on a leash. An imposing, moss-covered stone wall, low enough to see over but high enough to feel like a fortress, followed the curve of the road for nearly a mile before a discreet, unmarked opening appeared. Two massive, wrought-iron gates stood open, as if to say that their security did not depend on something as crude as a lock.

A long, winding drive took them deeper into the property, the house itself remaining hidden until the last possible moment. It was not a sprawling mansion in the Tudor or Victorian style, but a low, powerful structure of stone and cedar, designed to blend with the landscape rather than dominate it. It seemed to grow from the rocky bluff on which it sat, its wide windows staring out towards the vast, unbroken expanse of the Juan de Fuca Strait. It was a house that valued privacy and power over ostentatious display. A woman was waiting for them on the stone steps, her posture one of serene, unassailable authority. She was in her late seventies, her silver hair pulled back in a severe but elegant knot, her face a mask of aristocratic composure. She wore simple, expensive cashmere and radiated a stillness that felt more formidable than any overt show of force. This had to be Eleanor Blackwood, the matriarch, the keeper of the family’s formidable silence.

“Detective Chief Inspector Brent, Sergeant Sharma,” she said, her voice a cool, cultured alto. It was not a question. She already knew who they were. “I was told to expect you. Please, come inside. This business with Mr. Finch is most distressing.” She led them not into a grand foyer, but into a long, wood-paneled room that felt more like a private library or a museum’s study than a living room. A fire burned silently in a massive stone hearth. The wall of windows looked out onto a landscape of sculpted rock gardens and windswept trees, with the grey sea beyond. Sharma’s eyes made a swift, professional circuit of the room, noting the lack of visible cameras, the solid, heavy doors, the sheer isolation of the house. A person could scream in this room and the only thing that would hear them was the ocean.

“We appreciate you seeing us on such short notice, Mrs. Blackwood,” Brent began, adopting the role they had rehearsed. “As you know, Julian Finch has been reported missing. His last professional contact appears to have been with your family. We were hoping you could tell us about the work he was doing for you, and about your last interaction with him.” Eleanor Blackwood gestured to a pair of hard-backed leather chairs, seating herself opposite them. She exuded a polite, disarming concern. “Of course. It’s a terrible thing. Julian was a brilliant young man. A little… obsessive, perhaps, but brilliant. We commissioned him to create a definitive cartographical history of the estate. My late husband was a great believer in understanding the provenance of things. He felt the land had a memory. We simply wanted a record of it.” The echo of Brent’s own philosophy, spoken by this woman, was deeply unsettling. She was co-opting his language, using his own tools against him.

“And when did you last see him?” Sharma asked, her tone direct and business-like. “He was here three days ago,” Eleanor replied without hesitation. “He spent the morning walking the western parcel of the property, near the old quarry. He was quite excited, said his LIDAR scans had revealed some fascinating topographical anomalies. He left shortly after noon. That was the last we saw of him.” It was a perfect, seamless account, delivered with the practiced ease of someone accustomed to being believed. Brent watched her, looking for the tell, the flicker of unease beneath the placid surface. He decided to introduce a new variable.

“His sister mentioned he’d found something he called a ‘ghost lake’,” Brent said, his tone one of mild, academic curiosity. “A body of water that had been drained or filled in decades ago. Does that mean anything to you?” For the first time, a fractional change occurred. It wasn’t in her expression, which remained one of polite interest. It was in her stillness. It deepened, became more absolute, the way a predator freezes the moment before it strikes. “A ghost lake?” she repeated, the words tasting foreign in her mouth. “How wonderfully romantic. No, I can’t say that I’ve heard of such a thing. This estate is all rock and forest, Inspector. We are rather famously short on lakes, ghost or otherwise.” It was a denial, but it was a denial that was too complete, too smooth. Her stillness was the answer. He had found the redacted place in her memory.

She rose, a subtle signal that the interview was concluded. “I’m afraid I can’t be of more help. We have given our full cooperation. You’ll have my head of security, Mr. Thorne—no relation to your university friend, I’m sure—walk you out and provide you with a copy of Mr. Finch’s visitor logs.” The mention of Aris Thorne was a shot across the bow, a casual demonstration that she had done her research on them, too. They were dismissed. As they walked back towards their car, following the silent, imposing figure of her security chief, Sharma spoke in a voice too low for him to hear. “The windows in that room are triple-paned, reinforced frame. The doors are solid oak with high-security Medeco locks. And did you notice her hands? No jewelry, except for a signet ring. A man’s ring. Very old.”

Brent nodded, his own mind processing a different set of data. “She was lying about the lake. She knew exactly what I was talking about.” He paused as they reached their car, his gaze sweeping over the property. From this vantage point, he could see a wide, shallow valley curving away into the trees, a depression in the landscape that seemed unnaturally smooth and bowl-shaped. It was covered in meadow grass that was a slightly different shade of green from the surrounding forest floor. It was a scar, hiding in plain sight. “Julian Finch didn’t just find a ghost lake, Izzy,” he said, as he got into the car. “He found a burial ground. And I think the Blackwoods have just added him to it.”The drive back from the Blackwood estate was a descent from the rarefied, cold air of the highlands into the dense, complicated reality of the city. The silence in the car was no longer one of quiet contemplation; it was the tense, coiled quiet of two hunters who had just seen the tracks of a beast far larger and more dangerous than they had anticipated. Eleanor Blackwood’s polite, steely performance had been a masterpiece of misdirection, a velvet glove hiding an iron will to erase, to control, to forget. They had not been granted an interview; they had been subjected to a threat assessment, and they had likely been judged a significant threat.

“She’s a monarch,” Sharma said, her voice cutting through the hum of the engine as they reached the edge of the city. “That isn’t a house; it’s a court. And that security chief, Thorne, he’s not the captain of the guard. He’s the court executioner.” She expertly navigated a busy intersection, her focus on the road a counterpoint to the wild territory her mind was exploring. “They’re not just hiding something, Alistair. They’re curating reality. They’re tending to a multi-generational cover-up with the same meticulous care they tend to that forest.”

“Julian Finch was a cartographer of memory,” Brent murmured, his gaze lost in the reflection of the passing streetlights on the windscreen. “He found a part of their memory they had successfully amputated, and for that, they amputated him from the world.” The brutal simplicity of it settled in the car, cold and heavy. “We can’t go back there without an army, and we can’t get an army without proof. We need to find the story that Julian found. We need to map the ghost lake ourselves, from a distance.” They pulled into the precinct parking lot under the harsh glare of sodium lamps. Their plan was unspoken but perfectly understood. They would split, each returning to their native hunting ground. Sharma would hunt the living, and Brent would go to question the dead.

The next morning, while Sharma marshalled the digital resources of the precinct to build a fortress of data around the Blackwood family, Brent descended into the hushed, climate-controlled catacombs of the provincial Land Title and Survey Authority. This was a different kind of archive from the university’s, less concerned with ethnography and more with the brutal, legalistic geometry of ownership. Here, the land’s memory was recorded in deeds, survey plans, and property transfers. He requested the original township plans for the Metchosin district, specifically the parcel registered to the Blackwood family, tracing its lineage back to the original Crown grant of 1872.

For hours, he was immersed in a world of spidery copperplate script and fragile, linen-backed maps. He saw the Blackwood estate grow, absorbing smaller parcels of land through purchase and foreclosure, its borders expanding like a slow, inexorable ink blot. He found the family’s commissioned surveys, each one a masterpiece of technical drawing, each one showing the smooth, bowl-shaped valley as a simple meadow, unremarkable and nameless. The redaction was not a recent act; it was a tradition, a lie passed down from one generation’s cartographers to the next. He had to go deeper. He requested the pre-colonial surveys, the initial exploratory charts drawn by the Royal Engineers as they first carved the island into a grid of manageable squares. These were cruder documents, filled with estimations and sketches, their purpose more military than legal. And there, on a hydrographic chart from 1868, four years before the Blackwoods had arrived, he found it. The valley was not a meadow. It was filled with blue ink. The surveyor, a practical, unpoetic lieutenant in Her Majesty’s service, had labeled it simply ‘Blackfish Lake.’ But in the margins, in a slightly less formal script, he had added a note, a piece of ancillary intelligence for his superiors. *’Settlers avoid. The local Songhees call this place ‘the sunless water,’ claim it is a sick ground after the smallpox years. Ground is soft. Unsuitable for passage.’*

A chill, entirely unrelated to the archive’s regulated temperature, traced a line down Brent’s spine. The ghost lake was not just a drained body of water; it was a place of sickness and death, a place the original inhabitants of the land knew to avoid. The Blackwoods hadn't just acquired a piece of property; they had acquired a taboo, a place of bad ground. And instead of avoiding it, they had erased it. They hadn’t just drained a lake; they had buried a memory of plague. Brent suddenly understood the surgical precision of the cuts on Julian Finch’s map. It wasn't vandalism. It was a repetition of the original sin, a re-enactment of the act of making a sick place disappear.

Meanwhile, Sharma was hitting a wall of polished, expensive granite. She had run every member of the Blackwood family and their key personnel through every database she had access to, from financial records to criminal checks. The results were unnervingly perfect. The Blackwoods paid their taxes on time, had no outstanding lawsuits, and had never been so much as issued a speeding ticket. Their security chief, Michael Thorne, was a ghost. His official record showed a decorated but vaguely defined career in the Canadian Armed Forces, followed by an honorable discharge and a seamless transition to private security. But Sharma, using a deeper, less official set of search parameters she had cultivated over the years, found a trace. A single, redacted file from a CSIS internal review mentioned a Michael Thorne in connection with “extra-legal information management” during a corporate espionage case in the late 90s. He wasn’t a bodyguard. He was a cleaner, a man who made problems—and people—disappear.

As she stared at the dead end of her search, an email from the forensics tech working on Julian Finch’s laptop pinged in her inbox. The subject line was a single word: *’Got it.’* The tech had finally managed to reconstruct the corrupted file Finch had been working on just before he vanished. Sharma opened it. The image that filled her screen was not a map of lines and colours, but a ghostly, three-dimensional LIDAR scan, a picture of the earth itself rendered in shades of green and blue. It showed the shallow, bowl-shaped valley on the Blackwood estate. Finch, using the penetrating ground-scan function, had peeled back the skin of the meadow. And beneath it, a few feet under the manicured grass, the scan revealed a series of dense, regular, and horrifyingly familiar shapes. They were oblong, six to seven feet long, arranged in neat, overlapping rows. It was the unmistakable signature of a mass grave. Julian hadn't just found a 'sick ground.' He had found the bodies.

Her phone rang at the exact moment she was reaching for it to call Brent. It was him. “Izzy, I found it,” he said, his voice a low, excited hum. “The lake was a quarantine zone. A smallpox grave from the 1860s. The Blackwoods didn’t create the secret; they just inherited it. And they’ve been burying it ever since.” “They’re still burying it, Alistair,” she replied, her own voice grim as she stared at the spectral shapes on her screen. “Finch didn’t just find the history of the lake. He found what was at the bottom of it.” As she explained what the LIDAR scan showed, a profound and terrible silence settled over the line. They both understood. The Blackwoods were not just protecting their family’s reputation from a historical ugliness; they were actively concealing a crime scene that was over a hundred and fifty years old, and they had committed a fresh murder to do it. Just as Brent was about to speak, a notification popped up on Sharma’s screen. It was an internal security alert. A formal complaint had just been lodged against her and DCI Brent from the provincial Attorney General’s office, citing harassment and undue scrutiny of a private citizen, Eleanor Blackwood. They were ordered to cease all inquiries related to the Blackwood family, effective immediately. The monarch had made her move. She was no longer assessing the threat; she was neutralizing it.

The rain in Victoria didn't so much fall as it seeped. It crept from the low-slung, bruised-purple clouds and permeated everything, turning the crisp autumn air into a damp, woollen blanket. It beaded on the windscreen of the unmarked sedan, each droplet a tiny, distorted lens reflecting the grey pre-dawn world back at Detective Chief Inspector Alistair Brent. He watched the wipers sweep them away in a rhythmic, hypnotic arc. Squeegee, smear, clarity, repeat. It was a poor metaphor for his job, but on mornings like this, it was the only one that came to mind. The clarity was always fleeting. The smear was perpetual.

He’d left the university for this. Traded the scent of old paper and lukewarm coffee in a faculty lounge for the cloying, metallic tang of violence. Sometimes, he wondered if he’d made a colossal error. Professor Brent had a certain ring to it, a weight of comfortable authority. DCI Brent felt like a costume he was still learning to wear, the fabric stiff and unfamiliar across his shoulders. He was a man built for archives and bone fragments, for the quiet, patient story a skeleton tells centuries after the fact. He was not built for the screaming silence of a fresh crime scene.

His partner, Detective Sergeant Isabel Sharma, sat beside him, the glow of her phone casting a blueish tint on her sharp, focused features. She didn't share his ambivalence. Sharma was a cop down to her marrow, a creature of instinct and procedure who navigated the city’s underbelly with a cynical grace that Brent could only admire.

"Forensics are on site," she said, her voice cutting through the hum of the engine. "First responders confirmed the DOA. Uniforms have the perimeter locked down. It’s in Oak Bay. Big house, corner lot. The victim’s name is—was—Arthur Abernathy. Eighty-six years old. Retired provincial court judge."

Brent grunted, his gaze fixed on the passing mansions, their manicured hedges like dark, sleeping animals in the gloaming. Oak Bay. The city's capital of old money and even older residents. "Any obvious cause of death from the initial call?"

"Not that they'd tell dispatch," Sharma replied, tapping her screen. "Just 'unresponsive' and 'signs of a disturbance.' The call came from a private nurse who does twice-weekly wellness checks. Said the door was ajar. She found him in the study."

Brent's hands tightened on the wheel. An open door. That was unusual for this killer. Or perhaps not. Perhaps it was an evolution. He pushed the thought away, tucking it into the meticulous filing system of his mind. Assumptions were the enemy of observation. First, the data. Then, the hypothesis. It was the only way he knew how to function.

The house was exactly as he’d pictured it: a sprawling Tudor-revival, its dark timbers and white stucco a monument to a bygone era. It stood proud and imposing, even with the flashing disco of red and blue lights washing over its façade. A filigree of frost clung to the edges of the manicured lawn, sparkling under the strobing lights. It looked like a crime scene diorama, perfectly constructed and unnervingly still.

Brent pulled the car to the curb behind a forensics van and killed the engine. The silence that descended was immediate and profound, broken only by the whisper of the rain and the crackle of a distant police radio. For a moment, they both just sat there, looking at the house. It was a tomb. They were the archaeologists, about to disturb the dead.

"Let's get this over with," Sharma said, her voice flatter than before. She’d seen the last one. She knew what they were likely to find.

Brent nodded, his throat tight. He grabbed his briefcase from the back seat—a battered leather satchel that looked more suited to a lecture hall than a murder investigation—and stepped out into the cold. The air smelled of wet earth, salt from the nearby strait, and the faint, acrid scent of exhaust fumes. He pulled his trench coat tighter around him.

A uniformed constable, his face pale and young, lifted the yellow tape for them. "DCI Brent, Sergeant Sharma. He’s in the study. Straight through the hall, last door on the left. The ME is on his way."

"Thank you, Constable," Brent said, his eyes already scanning, absorbing. The grand entryway was immaculate. A polished mahogany table held a vase of dead flowers, their petals shrivelled and brown. A thick Persian rug, its intricate patterns muted in the dim light, covered the floor. The air inside was still and cold, carrying a faint, musty odour of dust and decay, but beneath it, something else. The coppery scent of shed blood.

Sharma moved ahead with purpose, her footsteps silent on the thick carpet. Brent followed more slowly, his academic's gaze taking in the details. The paintings on the wall—stately portraits of stern-faced ancestors. The grandfather clock, its pendulum frozen mid-swing. The house wasn't just a home; it was a museum of a life, and its final exhibit lay just down the hall.

The study was chaos contained. Books had been swept from shelves, their spines broken, pages splayed like fallen birds. A heavy crystal decanter lay shattered on the floor, its amber contents pooling into the fibres of the rug. But the desk, a massive piece of oak, was strangely neat. And in the high-backed leather chair behind it sat Arthur Abernathy.

He was slumped to one side, his head lolling at an unnatural angle. His eyes, cloudy and blue, were wide open, fixed on some point on the ceiling. He wore a silk dressing gown, the pattern faded with age. The cause of death seemed obvious; a brutalist punctuation mark of dark, dried blood stained the front of his gown, originating from a wound in his chest. But Brent knew that wasn't what Sharma was looking for. His own eyes were drawn, against his will, to the victim's head.

Sharma stood near the doorway, her arms crossed, her face a mask of professional detachment. "It's him," she stated, the two words heavy with resignation. "Same M.O."

Brent walked slowly into the room, his shoes crunching softly on the broken glass. He stopped a few feet from the chair, his gaze clinical, analytical. He forced himself to see the body not as the remains of a man, but as a collection of evidence. A text to be read. Arthur Abernathy’s fine, silver hair was matted with blood on one side, but it was the other side that held the killer’s signature. Both of them. The flesh was savaged, the cartilage severed with a crude, hacking motion. Where the judge’s ears should have been, there were only ragged, weeping hollows.

"The Collector strikes again," Brent murmured, the moniker tasting like ash in his mouth. The press had come up with it, of course. It was lurid and sensational, and entirely too accurate.

This was the third. The first had been a retired shipping magnate in Saanich. The second, a dowager socialite in the Uplands. All elderly. All wealthy. All from families that had been part of the island’s colonial bedrock for generations. And all found with their ears crudely excised from their skulls.

"No forced entry again," Sharma noted, pointing towards the French doors that led out to a garden. "Lock's intact. He let his killer in, just like the others. Offered them a drink, even." She nudged a second, unbroken glass on the corner of the desk with a gloved finger.

Brent’s gaze drifted from the savaged head of the victim to the floor. He crouched, his knees protesting. The Persian rug in here was even thicker, a deep pile of luxurious wool. He ran his fingers over it, feeling the texture. He was looking for something. A footprint. A fibre. Anything. And then he saw it. Not an imprint of a shoe, but something else. A pair of indentations, deep and symmetrical, about three feet from the desk. They were large, almost perfectly round, as if something incredibly heavy had been placed there. Or as if someone incredibly heavy had been standing there. Standing and watching.

"Isabel," he said, his voice low. "Come and look at this."

Sharma crouched beside him. "What is it? Footprints?"

"No. Not exactly." He traced the edge of the nearest depression. "The pile is crushed. Deeply. Whatever made these marks, it bore a significant amount of weight. More than an average person. Much more." He looked at the distance between the two marks. "And the stance is wide. Unusually so."

He thought of the other two crime scenes. They had been on hardwood and tile. No chance for impressions like this. This was new. This was data. His mind began to churn, the gears of the professor clicking into place. A large, heavy unsub. Pathologically strong, given the state of the victims. The murders weren't just killings; they were butcherings. Acts of profound, physical dominance.

"The nurse said she comes on Tuesdays and Fridays," Sharma said, rising to her feet. "Today is Tuesday. Last time she saw him was Friday afternoon. He was fine. That gives us a seventy-two-hour window, give or take."

"He was killed last night," Brent said, still staring at the indentations in the rug. "Rigor is well-established but not yet passing. Lividity is fixed. Based on the ambient temperature... I'd estimate he's been dead between twelve and eighteen hours." He looked up from the floor, his gaze sweeping the room again. "The killer is escalating. The first two were a month apart. This one is less than two weeks after Mrs. Albright. And he’s getting bolder. Leaving a door ajar. It’s a taunt."

The air in the room felt thick, charged with the echoes of unimaginable violence. Brent could almost feel it, a towering, hateful presence that had stood right where he was kneeling, had watched the life drain from the old judge, had performed its grotesque ritual, and had vanished back into the city's genteel façade. This wasn't about money. Nothing of value was ever taken, save for the grisly trophies. This was about something else. Something older and deeper. A rage that was almost geological in its force.

He rose to his feet, a cold certainty solidifying in his gut. This wasn’t just a serial killer. This was an exterminator. Someone was culling a specific herd, and they were doing it with a ferocity that defied all reason. His job was to find the reason, the aberrant logic that fuelled such hate. He looked at the face of the dead judge, the expression of surprise forever etched onto his features. A man who had represented the law his entire life, brought down by a force that clearly held the law in utter contempt. Brent felt a strange, unwelcome flicker of empathy. Not for the killer, but for the victim. For a man of order, like himself, consumed by a maelstrom of pure chaos. And in that chaos, Brent could feel a shape beginning to form—something vast, and strong, and utterly inhuman.

The forensics team moved around them with a quiet, practiced efficiency, their white Tyvek suits like ghosts in the opulent gloom. Brent paid them little mind, his focus entirely consumed by the twin depressions in the rug. They were the first real mistake the killer had made, the first physical signature left behind that wasn't part of the bloody, intentional tableau. It was a ghost's footprint, and Brent felt a thrill of academic discovery that was immediately soured by the context. He was cataloguing the stride of a monster.

"Heavy, you said?" Sharma's voice was low, pulling him from his reverie. She had her phone out again, but this time she was using its torch, playing the beam across the crushed fibres of the rug. "Like a bodybuilder? Or someone carrying equipment?"

"Potentially. Or just someone of exceptional size and mass," Brent mused, his mind sifting through possibilities. "The pressure is uniform. It's not the shifting weight of a person carrying something awkward. It's static. The indentations are almost perfectly round, like the base of... something." He trailed off, frustrated. Like the base of what? Columns? Statues? The thought was absurd. He ran a hand through his damp hair. "Whatever it was, it stood here for some time. Stood and watched. The placement gives it a perfect view of the victim in his chair."

A woman in a forensics suit, her name—Watanabe—stencilled on her back, approached them carefully. "DCI. Sergeant. We're getting the usual so far. Or rather, the lack of it. No prints that don't belong to the victim or his known associates. The shattered decanter is a bust, wiped clean before it was dropped. The secondary glass is also clean. Killer's tidy, except when he isn't." She gestured with a gloved hand towards the ransacked bookshelves. "The chaos is for show. It's directed. He didn't just sweep the shelves. Specific books were pulled, torn. The rest were just knocked over as a consequence."

Brent’s interest sharpened. "Which books?"

"Mostly legal texts. Case law, judicial theory. But also these," she said, pointing to a pile of leather-bound volumes near the fireplace. Their spines were embossed with gold leaf. "Family histories. Abernathy family, a few others. Looks like he was a bit of an amateur genealogist."

Brent’s mind latched onto the detail. Abernathy, the shipping magnate, the dowager. He knew without having to check. They were all founding families, their names etched onto street signs, parks, and university buildings across the city. They weren't just old money; they were the city's architects, the very people who had drawn the lines on the map. He walked over to the desk, careful to avoid the pools of congealing liquid. It was, as he’d noted, strangely pristine amidst the wreckage. A silver letter opener lay parallel to a neat stack of correspondence. A fountain pen was capped. The desk blotter was clean save for a single leather-bound day planner, open to the current week.

Sharma joined him, peering over his shoulder. "Find something, Professor?" Her use of the title was gentle, a recognition of the mode he’d shifted into.

His eyes scanned the page. Manicured loops of fountain pen ink detailed the judge's week. *Luncheon with rotary club. Pro-D lecture at UVic. Dr. Carmichael - 2pm.* But it was the entry for last night that held his attention. A single name, written in the same elegant script. *Mr. Clay.* No first name, no initial. Just a name, scheduled for 7 PM. Brent pointed to it. "The victim had an appointment."

"Mr. Clay," Sharma read. "Doesn't sound familiar. We'll run it. Could be our man, could be the gardener." She paused. "Still, he let him in. Sat down to have a drink with him. That suggests a degree of familiarity. Trust, even."

"Or deception," Brent countered softly, his gaze drifting back to the savaged body in the chair. "A wolf in sheep's clothing. Someone who knew how to present themselves to a man like Abernathy. Someone who spoke his language, who appeared to belong in a room like this, right up until the moment they didn't."

The arrival of the Medical Examiner, Dr. Kenji Tanaka, was announced by a gust of cold, rain-scented air from the hallway. He was a compact man, wiry and energetic, with eyes that had seen far too much to be shocked by anything. He offered Brent and Sharma a curt nod, his focus already zeroing in on the body. He circled the chair once, his movements economical.

"Well, Alistair, your boy is certainly keeping busy," Kenji said, his voice dry as bone dust as he began his preliminary examination. "Time of death, your estimate of twelve to eighteen hours is about right. Closer to eighteen, I'd say. Sometime between seven and nine last night." He leaned in, peering at the wound in Abernathy's chest. "Single stab wound. Large blade, but not particularly sharp. A lot of tearing. It was the force that did it. Went straight through the sternum. Takes a hell of a lot of strength to do that."

Kenji then moved his attention to the head, his expression becoming purely clinical. "And here's the signature. Same as the others. Hacking marks. He's not trying to be neat. This isn't surgery; it's desecration. He's taking a trophy, but he's also making a statement with the violence of the removal itself." He gently tilted the judge's head. "No defensive wounds on the hands or arms. He was likely taken by complete surprise. Dead or dying before he even knew what was happening."

Brent stared at the ME, then back at the indentations in the carpet. Incredible strength. A wide, solid stance. A single, overwhelming blow. The image in his mind grew sharper, more defined. He felt the hair on his arms prickle. He crouched down again, next to the strange impressions, trying to reconcile the pieces. A person of immense size and strength, who could appear unassuming enough to be invited in for a drink by a retired judge. It didn't fit. The two profiles were at war with each other.

"Kenji," Brent began, his voice barely above a whisper. "The force required... is it outside the bounds of a normal human?"

Dr. Tanaka paused, considering. "It's at the very peak of what a large, powerful man in a state of extreme adrenaline could accomplish. Think powerlifter, or a strongman competitor having the worst day of his life. It’s possible. But it's... notable."

Brent nodded slowly, his theory feeling less and less absurd. He stood and addressed the forensics lead. "Watanabe, I want casts of these two impressions in the carpet. I want every fibre analyzed. I want to know the precise depth and distribution of pressure. Treat them like the most important piece of evidence we have. Because I think they are."

He turned and walked out of the study, the coppery smell of blood clinging to his coat. He needed air, even the damp, heavy air of the rainy morning. Sharma followed him out into the grand hallway, where the dead flowers in the vase seemed to droop a little lower.

"Something's not right, Izzy," he said, stopping by the front door. He looked out through the leaded glass panels at the flashing lights painting the wet street. "The pieces don't fit. The social grace required to get in the door, and the sheer animal brutality of the act itself. The meticulous cleanup, and the taunting chaos. It's like two different killers."

"Or one killer with a very fractured personality," she offered, though her tone suggested she shared his unease. "So what's the next move? We have a name, 'Mr. Clay.' We have the genealogical connection between the victims. We have... heavy footprints."

"We treat them as separate lines of inquiry that must, eventually, intersect," Brent stated, the professor outlining a syllabus. "You run the name. Dig into the judge's life, his finances, his rulings. See if any 'Mr. Clay' had a reason to hold a grudge. I'll take the family histories. I'll go back to the archives, my old hunting grounds. This rage feels old. The targeting is specific. This isn't about Abernathy, the man. This is about Abernathy, the symbol. I want to know what that symbol meant."

They stepped outside, back into the soft hiss of the rain. The young constable shivered by the police tape, his face still wan. The world was waking up around them, the sky lightening from bruised purple to a sodden, featureless grey. Another mansion, another tomb, another set of gruesome trophies taken. The Collector was hunting the city's past, and Brent, the man who had dedicated his life to understanding it, was the only one who could possibly hunt him back. The weight of it settled on his shoulders, more familiar now, but no less heavy. The clarity was gone. The smear was back.

The drive back to the precinct was a silent, grey affair. Sharma typed furiously on her phone, coordinating with dispatch and compiling preliminary notes, her focus an impenetrable shield. Brent just drove, the squeegee-smear of the wipers keeping a rhythm with the thoughts turning over in his head. *Four hundred kilograms. Static bipedal load.* The words from Watanabe’s preliminary text to Sharma echoed, nonsensical and terrifying. Nine hundred pounds. It wasn’t a man. It couldn't be. He pictured the indentations in the plush rug again, so neat, so deliberate. The creature, whatever it was, had stood there, a living statue of immense weight, and watched a man die.

He dropped Sharma at the bustling headquarters, a glass-and-steel box that always felt too bright and too loud. He had no desire to enter the warren of cubicles, to face the whiteboards already filling up with the grim arithmetic of the Abernathy murder. He needed a different kind of quiet, a different kind of order.

"You're sure about this?" Sharma asked as he remained in the driver's seat. "I can put a team on the family histories, run the names through the database."

"A database won't have what I'm looking for," Brent said, his hand already on the worn leather of his satchel. "This isn't in a file, Izzy. It's in the sediment. I'll call you if I find anything."

She gave him a long, searching look, then nodded. "Alright, Professor. Go dig up your bones."

The Royal BC Museum and Archives was his real home. He’d spent more hours in its hushed, climate-controlled vaults than he had in his own apartment. The moment he walked through the public entrance and past the chattering school groups towards the staff entrance, he felt the stiff fabric of DCI Brent loosen. The air changed, losing the scent of wet asphalt and tasting instead of acid-free paper, bookbinding glue, and time itself. Here, the silence wasn't screaming; it was whispering stories he knew how to interpret.

A registrar named Helen, a woman with whom he’d shared countless lukewarm coffees over dusty folio tables, looked up from her desk in surprise. Her eyes widened at the sight of him. He’d been a fixture here, the eccentric academic whose specialty was the forensic archaeology of the colonial period. Now he was a ghost in a trench coat.

"Alistair," she breathed, a smile touching her lips. "Don't tell me you've come back to us. Did the real world finally prove too disappointing?"

"More distressing than disappointing, Helen," he said, managing a faint smile of his own. "I need access to the private collections. The land grant ledgers for the Saanich Peninsula, 1870 to 1900. And the genealogical records for the Henderson, Albright, and Abernathy families."

Helen’s smile faded as she processed the names. Even an archivist, insulated from the daily news, had heard of the Collector’s victims. She simply nodded, her expression shifting to one of quiet purpose. "Of course. Reading Room C. I'll have them brought up for you."

An hour later, Brent was surrounded. Not by chaos, but by a meticulously ordered history. He had laid out the family trees of the three victims, their lineages sprawling across the heavy vellum like ancient, gnarled trees. Henderson, the shipping magnate. Albright, the socialite. Abernathy, the judge. He traced their lines back with a practiced finger. All three families had arrived in the colony of Vancouver Island in the 1860s. All three had acquired vast tracts of land, their initial wealth exploding into dynastic fortunes built on timber, shipping, and real estate. They were the men who had built the province, their portraits hanging in the very legislature building a few blocks away.

He cross-referenced their holdings, pulling out the heavy, cloth-bound ledgers. His gloved fingers traced the spidery copperplate script detailing deeds and transfers. And then he found it. 1888. A joint acquisition. A sprawling, two-hundred-acre parcel of waterfront land in what was then the rural outskirts of the city, and was now the most exclusive part of Oak Bay. The signatories on the grant application were Magnus Henderson, Charles Albright, and William Abernathy—the great-grandfathers of the three victims.

His phone vibrated against the solid oak of the table, a jarring buzz in the sepulchral silence. He stepped into the corridor to answer it. "Brent."

"It's a ghost town," Sharma's voice said, tight with frustration. "Mr. Clay. No one in Abernathy's life knows him. Not his bridge partners, not his few remaining relatives, not his golf club. We've run the name against every disgruntled litigant who ever stood before him. Nothing. It's like the name was plucked from thin air."

"Because it was," Brent said, his eyes fixed on the name on the ledger through the reading room window. "Not from thin air. From the past. I've found a connection, Izzy. All three victims' families were co-signatories on a massive land deal in 1888."

"A business deal from over a century ago? That's the motive?" she asked, her skepticism palpable even over the phone.

"It's more than that," Brent continued, his mind racing. "It wasn't just any land." He walked back to the table and picked up a corresponding survey map, its creases fragile as a dragonfly’s wing. He spread it out. He could see the neat, ruled lines of the parcel granted to the three families. But the surveyor, a man of methodical detail, had also sketched in what was there before. A cluster of markings, labeled in a faint, spidery hand: *Tl’ches Village Site – Cleared.* "They bought the land out from under the Songhees people. Displaced a whole village. According to these records, the petition to have the village cleared and the residents 'relocated' was championed by Henderson, Albright, and Abernathy."

A silence stretched over the line. Then, Sharma spoke, her voice low. "Okay. So it's a historical grievance. A big one. But why now? And who is Mr. Clay?"

"I'm getting to that part," Brent said. He scanned the associated paperwork, the official authorizations from the colonial administration. "The petition to clear the land had to be approved by the territorial magistrate. The man who signed the order, who made the displacement legal and final, was a magistrate by the name of Elias Clay."

The pieces slammed together with the force of a physical blow. Sharma let out a sharp breath. "Jesus. So the killer isn't 'Mr. Clay.' He's invoking the name. It's a calling card. A message for the victim."

"A final judgment," Brent murmured, looking at the names on the page. Henderson, Albright, Abernathy. The beneficiaries. Clay. The enabler. The killer was serving a subpoena from the grave. He was methodically erasing the lines of those who had erased his ancestors. The ransacked genealogy books at the Abernathy house—the killer was confirming the bloodline, making sure he had the right descendant.

"Alistair," Sharma's voice cut in again, pulling him from his thoughts. "I just got the full report from Watanabe's team. The casts of the impressions. They've built a 3D model. The weight is one thing, but the shape... they're not shoe prints. They're almost completely flat on the bottom. No arch, no heel, no discernible tread. Like... like the feet of a statue. A nine-hundred-pound statue that can walk into a house and tear a man apart."

Brent looked down at the old map, at the sketch of the long-gone village. He thought of the stories he’d read in his academic days, the Coast Salish myths, the legends told by the very people whose history was a footnote on this map. Stories of wild men of the woods, of giants, of powerful, non-human beings who walked the forests of the island. Stories the settlers had dismissed as primitive folklore. He thought of the crude hacking marks around the victims' heads, the desecration. The taking of the ears. A symbolic act. *You did not listen then, so you will not listen now.* The rage wasn't just historical; it felt elemental.

"The killer isn't human," he said, the words coming out before he could stop them. It was a leap, a wild, unprofessional hypothesis, but it was the only one that fit the data. The impossible weight. The inhuman strength. The ancient, geological rage.

"Boss?" Sharma's voice was sharp with concern. "Don't go off the deep end on me. It's a big guy. A freakishly big guy in weird shoes."

"No, Izzy," Brent said, his voice dropping to a near whisper as he stared at the name of the erased village. "It’s not a man. I think we're hunting a ghost."

There was a long, static-filled silence on the line, so profound Brent could hear the hum of the fluorescent lights in Sharma’s office sixty blocks away. He imagined her leaning forward, her brow furrowed, running the words through her procedural filter and finding no box for them to fit. The rain pattered against the glass of the archive corridor, a soft, insistent drumming.

"A ghost, Alistair?" Sharma’s voice was dangerously calm, the tone she used just before she eviscerated a junior constable for contaminating a scene. "Are you concussed? Did you hit your head? We have physical evidence. Castings of impressions. A murder weapon. That's not a ghost, that's a person. A very large, very strong, very disturbed person."

"The evidence doesn't point to a person, Izzy, it points to an impossibility," Brent argued, his voice low and urgent. "What kind of person weighs nine hundred pounds and leaves perfectly round, flat footprints? What kind of man can punch through a sternum with a blunt object as if it were cardboard? This isn't a human rage; it's something else. Primal. It doesn’t feel like it comes from one man's lifetime. It feels… inherited."

"So, what, it's a family curse? A vengeful spirit passed down through the generations?" Her sarcasm was a bludgeon. "Let me know when you plan to hold a séance in the interrogation room. In the meantime, I'm going to do my job. I'm going to trace the descendants of Magistrate Elias Clay. Maybe one of them is a six-foot-eight powerlifter with a history degree and a chip on his shoulder the size of the provincial legislature. It's a long shot, but it's a damn sight more productive than chasing phantoms."

"Do that," Brent said, conceding the point. He knew how he sounded. He was the Professor, after all, the man lost in his books. But the facts were the facts, and the facts were telling a story that defied every rule of his new profession. "Run down the Clays. I'm going to stay with the history. We're looking at the same beast, Izzy. We're just coming at it from different sides of the forest."

He hung up before she could argue further, the silence of the archive settling around him once more. He looked back at the map, at the faded ink that marked the erasure of a community. *Tl’ches.* The name felt important. He carefully folded the map and returned the ledgers to their carts, his mind already miles away. He left the quiet sanctuary of the archives and walked back out into the persistent, seeping rain, a man with a new and terrible purpose. He wasn't just a detective anymore, nor was he merely an academic. He was becoming a mythographer, charting the path of a living legend.

The University of Victoria campus was a maze of concrete and glass woven into the coastal forest. It was Brent’s old territory, and he navigated its winding pathways with an unconscious familiarity. He bypassed the new, gleaming social sciences building and headed for the Cornett, a Brutalist concrete structure that housed the Anthropology department. It was a building as stark and uncompromising as the man he had come to see.

Dr. Aris Thorne’s office was less an office and more a dragon's hoard. Books were stacked in precarious, gravity-defying towers. Shelves overflowed with First Nations art—carved masks, woven cedar hats, intricate silver bracelets. The air was thick with the scent of old paper, beeswax polish, and Thorne’s ever-present pipe tobacco. Thorne himself was a theatrical counterpoint to Brent’s grey asceticism: a portly man with a wild mane of white hair, a tweed jacket worn thin at the elbows, and a booming voice that had captivated lecture halls for forty years.

"Alistair! My prodigal colleague!" Thorne bellowed, rising from behind a desk that was barely visible beneath strata of journals and artifacts. "Have you finally tired of playing policeman? Come to beg for your old office back? I’m afraid I’ve already claimed your bookshelf space for my collection of pre-contact fishing hooks."

"Aris," Brent said, closing the door behind him. "I'm not back. This is business. Official business."

Thorne’s jovial expression sobered. He gestured to the only other chair, a leather monstrosity shedding its stuffing. "Then this is a sad day. What horror brings you from the city’s charnel houses to my humble archive of human culture?"

Brent didn't sit. He remained standing in the small clearing by the door, the DCI costume feeling stiff again. He decided to present the problem as a thought experiment, an academic puzzle. "I'm investigating a series of deaths," he began. "The victims share a common ancestry, a connection to a specific historical injustice. The displacement of a Songhees village in the 1880s."

Thorne nodded slowly, his sharp eyes missing nothing. "Tl’ches. I know it. A nasty piece of colonial business. Legalized theft, pure and simple."

"The killer seems to be targeting the descendants of the men who orchestrated it," Brent continued. "But it's the nature of the killer that presents the conundrum. The forensic evidence suggests a perpetrator of impossible physical characteristics. A weight of over four hundred kilograms. Immense strength. And a unique calling card—the ears of the victims are removed."

He watched Thorne’s face carefully. The anthropologist’s initial clinical interest slowly curdled into something else. A deep, troubled stillness. The pipe in his hand, which he had been packing with fresh tobacco, lay forgotten. He stared at a point just past Brent’s shoulder, his gaze turned inward, sifting through a different kind of archive.

"The ears," Thorne whispered, the single word cutting through the smoky air. "You're certain?"

"Brutally removed. A desecration," Brent confirmed, his heart beginning to beat a little faster. He was on the right path.

Thorne sank back into his chair, the leather groaning in protest. He seemed to age ten years in ten seconds. "There are stories," he said, his voice no longer booming but a low, conspiratorial murmur. "Obscure ones. Stories the elders rarely share, because they are not meant for outsiders. They aren't the public tales of Raven and Thunderbird. They are stories of justice. And of consequences."

He gestured vaguely at a towering bookshelf. "In some Coast Salish traditions, the land itself has memory. A wrong done to the land—a great theft, a poisoning, a massacre—doesn't just fade. It soaks into the soil, into the clay, into the very stones. And sometimes, when the wrong is great enough, the memory can take form. It can be given shape by a powerful ritual. A vessel of vengeance, created to balance the scales."

Brent felt a cold knot tighten in his stomach. "A vessel?"

"They call it different names in different language groups. But the elements are always the same. It is not a spirit or a ghost. It is a physical being, an animate object. A golem, if you want a European parallel, but that’s a clumsy comparison. This is not a servant. It is an engine of justice." Thorne leaned forward, his eyes locking onto Brent’s. "It is formed from the clay of the stolen land, from the stones of the river, from the anger of the dispossessed. That is why it is so heavy. It carries the weight of the earth itself. It takes the ears as a symbol. A message to the descendants of those who would not listen to the pleas of the people they were destroying. It is a creature of absolute, single-minded purpose: to extinguish the bloodline of the injustice."

The room was silent save for the ticking of an old clock and the distant drumming of the rain. The wild hypothesis Brent had offered Sharma no longer felt wild. It felt chillingly, terrifyingly plausible. He was no longer hunting a man, or even a ghost. He was hunting a piece of the earth itself, animated by a century-old rage. He was hunting something that, by all rational laws, could not and should not exist.

Brent felt as if the floor had dropped out from under him, leaving him suspended in the thick, smoky air of Thorne’s office. The academic in him was electrified, piecing together mythology and ethnography into a coherent, if unbelievable, narrative. The detective was appalled. He was a creature of fact and observable data, and he had just been handed a folk tale as a murder weapon. The two halves of his identity were at war, and the battleground was the churning space behind his own eyes.

"So you're telling me," Brent said, his voice carefully level, forcing the DCI to take command of his tongue, "that someone, or something, is using a ritual to animate a monster made of mud to commit these murders."

"I am telling you what the stories say," Thorne corrected gently, his brief moment of shock passing, replaced by the familiar spark of academic debate. "I am providing a cultural context for the evidence you have presented. Your ‘impossible’ weight is explained by a body of earth and stone. Your ‘inhuman’ strength is the force of a land wronged. Your 'symbolic' removal of the ears is the literal enactment of a traditional curse. Is it more unbelievable than a nine-hundred-pound man in special shoes who manages to be invited in for sherry by his victims?"

The question hung in the air, unanswerable. Brent had no reply, because Thorne was right. The mythological explanation, as insane as it was, fit the bizarre facts more neatly than any rational theory he could devise. He felt a profound sense of dislocation, as if the solid ground of his profession was turning to mist. He was a man who read skeletons, not tea leaves. But the skeleton of this case was malformed, its bones made of something other than proof.

"Who would know how to do this?" Brent asked, the question feeling absurd as it left his lips. "This ritual. It's not something you'd find on the internet."

"No," Thorne agreed, tamping his unlit pipe with a stained thumb. "It would be guarded knowledge. Deeply guarded. Passed down through a specific line, a family of lore-keepers or shamans who felt the Tl’ches displacement not as a historical event, but as a personal, familial wound. You are not looking for a man with a grudge, Alistair. You are looking for a man with a god-like power and a righteous, terrible sense of purpose. You are looking for a sorcerer."

The word hung in the office, and Brent had to physically restrain himself from recoiling. He gave Thorne a curt, formal nod, the mask of the DCI slipping back into place. It was a flimsy shield against the abyss that had just opened up before him. "Thank you for your time, Aris. This has been… informative." He turned and walked out, leaving the anthropologist sitting in his hoard of history, a modern man who had just handed a policeman a map to the mythic age.

The rain was a cold shock as he stepped back outside. It felt real, tangible, a comfort after the speculative haze of Thorne’s office. He got into his car and sat for a long moment, the engine off, the rhythmic sweep of the wipers the only sound. A sorcerer. An engine of justice made from clay. He felt a hysterical laugh bubble in his chest but forced it down. He couldn’t tell Sharma. He couldn't tell anyone. They would pull his badge before the words were even cold. If he was going to walk this path, he had to walk it alone.

Meanwhile, Detective Sergeant Isabel Sharma was in her own version of an archive, albeit one that smelled of stale coffee and disinfectant. The whiteboards in the incident room were covered in spidery handwriting, connecting victims to timelines, timelines to forensics reports. It was a cathedral of data, but the central altar was empty. In the space marked 'SUSPECT', there was only a large, angry question mark. Sharma stood before it, chewing on the end of a pen, her patience worn thin.

Brent's 'ghost' theory had irritated her more than she let on, not because it was outlandish, but because a small, unprofessional part of her felt the same disquiet. The facts refused to line up. But she was a cop, and cops followed procedure. Procedure meant chasing down the name from the victim’s planner. She had put two junior detectives on the task, and after four hours of sifting through digital and paper records, they had found him. Walter Clay. Great-grandson of Magistrate Elias Clay. Eighty-nine years old. Resident of the Cedar Hill Extended Care Facility.

Sharma drove to the facility herself. It was a low, sprawling building that smelled of floor polish and cooked cabbage. She found Walter Clay in a brightly lit sunroom, sitting in a wheelchair, a plaid blanket across his lap, staring out at a rain-sodden garden. He was a wisp of a man, with watery blue eyes and skin as thin and translucent as parchment. He looked at Sharma’s badge with a gentle, slightly befuddled curiosity.

"Magistrate Elias Clay?" he repeated, his voice a soft, papery rustle. "I’m afraid I don't know the name, dear. My father was a postman. His father, too, I think. We’re not a very grand family, you see." He offered a sweet, harmless smile. Sharma spent twenty minutes asking him about his life, his family, his past, but it was clear this man couldn't have orchestrated a trip to the dining hall, let alone a series of brutal, ritualistic murders. He was a biological dead end, the last of his line, a forgotten footnote to his great-grandfather’s consequential life. As she left, Sharma felt a familiar wave of frustration. The one solid clue they had, the only name, had led to a room that smelled of decay and a man waiting patiently for his own end.

As she got back in her car, her phone buzzed. It was Watanabe from forensics. "Got something weird for you, Sergeant," the tech said without preamble. "We did a spectral analysis on the fibres from those impressions in Abernathy's rug. Along with the wool and standard household dust, we found high concentrations of mineral particulates. Specifically, blue-grey clay common to the coastline, and trace amounts of something else. Pulverized olivine and quartz. Almost like the fibres were ground into a fine-grained stone paste." Sharma felt a chill that had nothing to do with the damp air. She thought of Brent's words. *A body of earth and stone.* She shook her head, dismissing it. "Thanks, Watanabe. Keep digging."

Brent didn’t drive back to the precinct. He pulled the old surveyor's map from his satchel and spread it across the passenger seat, the car’s dome light illuminating the fragile paper. He traced the lines of the old Tl’ches village site, now a grid of streets bearing the names of English counties. But his eyes were drawn to a feature the developers had been forced to accommodate: a deep, narrow ravine that cut through the properties, carrying a creek down to the choppy waters of the strait. It was a scar of wildness left on the face of the manicured suburb. A place where the original land, the stolen land, might still be accessible.

He drove the quiet, winding streets of Oak Bay, the unmarked sedan gliding past stone walls and wrought-iron gates. He found the ravine, a dark slash of green between two palatial homes. A discreet municipal sign marked it as a public footpath. He parked the car, pulled his trench coat tight, and stepped into the deepening twilight. The air under the canopy of ancient cedars was thick and cool, heavy with the smell of loam and decaying leaves. The sound of the city vanished, replaced by the rush of the swollen creek and the steady drip of water from a million green needles.

He followed the muddy path downwards, his city shoes slipping on wet roots. He was operating on pure, academic instinct now, the same instinct that had once led him to a forgotten Roman burial ground in the north of England. He was looking for a place that felt disturbed, a place that didn't fit the natural decay of the forest. The creek bed was slick with the same blue-grey clay Watanabe had found on the rug. He was in the right place. Then he saw it. A small clearing, just off the path, shielded from view by a thick curtain of salal bushes. The ground was a mess of churned mud and deep gouges. It looked like someone had been digging here, not with shovels, but with their bare hands, excavating great clumps of the heavy, wet clay.

In the centre of the clearing, half-buried in the muck, was a small, dark object. Brent knelt, his knees sinking into the cold earth. He carefully pulled it free. It was a small carving, no bigger than his thumb, worked from a piece of dark yew wood. It was a human figure, crudely rendered, but its features were clear enough. Its mouth was open in a silent scream. And where its ears should have been, there were only smooth, blank hollows. It was a totem. A prayer. A schematic for a monster. The sorcerer had left a piece of his spellbook behind.

Brent’s fingers, numb with cold, closed around the small wooden effigy. He held it in his palm, the rain-darkened yew wood surprisingly heavy, dense with purpose. It was a nexus point, the place where folklore and forensics met. He could see the headline in the *Times Colonist*, the sneering dismissal from his superintendent: *DCI solves triple homicide with pagan doll*. He would be a laughingstock, his career traded for a professorship ending not in comfortable retirement, but in a padded room. Yet the object in his hand felt more real, more substantial, than any theory the forensics team could concoct. It was a key, and he knew it fit a lock that no one else could see. He carefully placed the carving into an evidence bag, the plastic crinkling in the profound quiet of the ravine. He was now in possession of exhibit A in a case that could never go to court.

Back at the precinct, Sharma stood in the harsh glare of the incident room, the forensic report from Watanabe feeling like a burning coal in her hand. *Blue-grey clay. Pulverized olivine and quartz.* The words were scientifically inert, yet they formed a deeply unsettling poetry. She projected the 3D model of the footprints onto the main screen. They looked less like footprints and more like the bases of two industrial stanchions, perfectly round and utterly alien. She could feel the stares of the other detectives in the room, their focus shifting from the board to her, waiting for direction. They were looking for a person of interest, a vehicle, a weapon. She had footprints made of stone and dirt.

"Forget the how," she said abruptly, her voice sharp enough to cut through the low hum of the room. "The 'how' is a sideshow. Let's focus on the 'why.' The motive is a hundred-and-thirty-year-old land grab. The victims are the descendants of the thieves. So let's look at the other side of the transaction." She turned to the whiteboard, picked up a black marker, and drew a new box, connecting it to the victims with a thick, angry line. "Tl’ches. The Songhees village that was cleared. I want to know everything. I want a list of every family that was displaced. I want to know where they went. I want every living descendant who still lives on the island. I want to know who the community leaders are, the historians, the activists. Somewhere in that history, somewhere in that diaspora, is a person who inherited this rage. Find them." The team, grateful for a concrete direction, no matter how broad, scattered to their desks, their keyboards clicking into a sudden, furious rhythm. Sharma was left alone in front of the board, staring at the impossible footprints and the very real name of a wronged people.

Brent drove with a slow, deliberate calm, the city lights smearing across his wet windscreen. He didn't go towards his empty apartment or the hostile brightness of the precinct. He drove back towards the university, the small, bagged totem in his pocket a cold weight against his leg. He found Dr. Thorne still in his office, the lights on, a thin tendril of pipe smoke curling towards the ceiling. He hadn't moved, as if he had been waiting, knowing Brent would be back. Brent closed the door and, without a word, took out the evidence bag and placed it on the one clear corner of the desk.

Thorne put down his pipe and leaned forward, his spectacles slipping down his nose. He peered at the small, dark figure suspended in its plastic cocoon. His jovial, academic face slackened into a mask of profound gravity. He didn't touch the bag, but his eyes traced the carving's crude lines as if it were radioactive. "God help us," he whispered, the words barely audible. "You found it at the source. At the place of its making." He looked up at Brent, his eyes dark with a fear that was ancient and deeply felt. "This isn't just a carving, Alistair. This is its heart. Or its mind, perhaps. An anchor that binds it to its purpose."

"What purpose?" Brent asked, his voice low. "Just to kill?"

"To complete a sentence," Thorne corrected. "This effigy is a sympathetic link. The creator carves it in the image of the injustice. See the blank spaces where the ears should be? It is a constant reminder of why the entity was made. The creature—the vessel—is not truly sentient. It is a tool, a weapon animated by a will greater than its own. It carries out its task and then, I imagine, it returns to the earth, dormant, until it is called upon again." Thorne finally reached out a hesitant finger and tapped the plastic over the figure's head. "To stop the vessel, you must find the person who made this. The ritual requires a phenomenal focus, an unbroken line of cultural knowledge, and a pain so deep it can call upon the land itself for aid. This is the work of one person. The hand that shaped the clay is the one you must find."

Brent felt a cold clarity descend. The case had finally resolved into a single point of focus. It wasn't about forensics or timelines anymore. It was about finding one person in a city of half a million. A person who walked in two worlds, the modern and the mythic. A person who could hold a conversation, pay their taxes, and, in the quiet of a rain-soaked ravine, command the very soil to rise up and kill. He took the bagged effigy from the desk, the responsibility of it settling on his shoulders like a lead mantle.

"How?" Brent asked, the simple question encompassing the vastness of the task ahead. "How do I find a sorcerer?"

Thorne picked up his cold pipe, his hands trembling slightly. "You look for the wound, Alistair. This kind of power is not born from intellectual curiosity. It is born from suffering. Find the family line among the Tl’ches descendants that has suffered the most, that has held onto the memory of the injustice with the most fervor. Find the keeper of the stories, the one who feels the weight of that stolen land not as history, but as a phantom limb, an ache that has never, ever gone away." As Brent walked out into the night, the weight in his pocket was no longer just evidence; it was a compass, and it was pointing directly into the heart of a people’s pain. At the same time, miles away, Sergeant Sharma was pinning the first photograph to her new section of the whiteboard. It was a black-and-white archival image of a stern-faced Songhees elder, identified in the notes as one of the last residents to be forcibly removed from Tl’ches. She and Brent were now on the very same path, though one was following a paper trail of descendants while the other was following a trail of magic and tears.

The drive away from the university was a journey through a fractured city. On one level, Victoria was a tidy grid of streets, traffic lights, and bylaws—a place of order that DCI Brent was sworn to uphold. On another, the one revealed by Thorne and the yew-wood carving, it was a palimpsest of older, deeper magics, a place where the soil itself could hold a grudge. Brent felt himself caught between these two worlds, a translator for a language he was only just beginning to learn. He drove not to the station, but to a small, all-night cafe on the waterfront, a place frequented by fishermen and ferry workers. He needed the ballast of ordinary life, the clatter of ceramic on formica and the smell of frying bacon, to keep from being swept away by the current of the impossible.

He sat in a cracked vinyl booth, the evidence bag a cold lump against the warmth of a coffee mug. He couldn't log the effigy. He couldn’t submit a report stating his primary lead was an object of sympathetic magic identified by an anthropology professor. The moment he did, he would be on administrative leave, sent for a psych evaluation, and the case would be handed to someone who would chase the nine-hundred-pound man in special shoes right into a brick wall. His two paths, professor and detective, had finally diverged so sharply he could no longer walk both. He had to choose. He chose the one that, against all logic, felt like the truth.

His phone buzzed, and Sharma’s name lit up the screen. He let it go to voicemail, picturing her in the bright, sterile incident room, marshaling her forces, chasing down paper trails. She was building a case; he was following a story. But he knew, with a sudden, sinking certainty, that both their paths had to lead to the same place: the descendants of Tl’ches. Sharma would be looking for a motive rooted in politics and protest. He was looking for one rooted in pain and ritual. He needed her data, her lists of names and family trees, but he could not tell her why.

The next morning, Brent bypassed his own office and went straight to the incident room. It was humming with a tense, focused energy. The whiteboard was now dominated by a complex web of names, dates, and archival photographs under the heading Sharma had created. She saw him enter, and her expression was a mixture of relief and irritation. "Nice of you to join us," she said, her voice low. "Find any more ghosts in your library?"

"I pursued a line of inquiry," he said, his tone neutral, non-committal. He gestured at the board. "This is good. This is the right direction. Who is the keeper of their history? Who are the elders?"

Sharma’s eyes narrowed, searching his face for some sign of whatever strange detour he’d taken. "We’re cross-referencing band council records with protest registries and land claim filings. We've identified a few families who have been consistently vocal about the Tl'ches claim for generations. The Lamberts. The Jacks. Their names come up again and again. David Lambert is the current face of the movement. He’s an activist, a firebrand. Writes scathing op-eds, organizes the annual protest march. He fits the profile of someone with a deep, abiding grudge."

Brent looked at the photo of David Lambert pinned to the board. He was a man in his forties with an angry, intelligent face and eyes that burned with conviction. He looked like a man who would fight the government with lawsuits and picket signs. He did not look like a man who would creep into a Tudor mansion and perform a blood ritual. "He's too loud," Brent said, thinking aloud. "This killer is silent. The rage is deep, but the action is quiet, almost invisible."

"Or he's hiding in plain sight," Sharma countered, tapping Lambert's photo. "Putting on a public face while he pursues a more… direct form of justice. We're getting a warrant for his place. Computer, phone records, checking for any large, unusual purchases. Maybe he bought himself a Golem kit on Amazon."
